presentation.title: Farms in floodplains
presentation.runninghead: Farm damage avoided by flood regulation.
presentation.description: Values resulting from flood regulation by ecosystems, including precipitation, ecosystems capable of providing infiltration or detention of flood waters, and farmland at risk of flooding. Flow models are used to connect beneficiaries to potential sources of flood water and quantify the action of natural "sinks" that slow, detain, or infiltrate flood water.

page.name: Assessment of farmland at risk from flooding
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This model considers floodplain farmland as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. Depending on their magnitude and timing, floods can have devastating effects on crops. These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map farms at risk of flooding, we simply intersect farmland with floodplain extents data for either the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Assessment of public assets at risk from flooding
page.title: Introduction
page.runninghead: Public assets at risk from flooding.
page.description: This model considers protection of public infrastructure as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. Public infrastructure (e.g., transportation, energy, or water infrastructure) can be damaged by floodwater or the use of such infrastructure can be impaired by inundation (e.g., roads being impassable due to flooding). These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map public infrastructure at risk of flooding, we simply intersect roads, railways, or other infrastructure with data delimiting the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Assessment of residents at risk from flooding
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This model considers protection of human life and housing as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. For people living in flood zones, floodwater can destroy housing and personal property and pose a risk to human lives. These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map housing at risk of flooding, we simply housing data (where available) or NLCD developed land with data delimiting the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Annual precipitation
page.description:
Annual precipitation.

Role in models

Precipitation data are used as the "source" of floodwater. Data are currently at an annual time scale; event-based models may be added to the ARIES system as we better integrate external data and models to allow flood modeling at finer time scales. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and beneficiaries at risk of flooding.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional stage
page.title: Successional stage
page.description:
Forest successional stage is an important determinant of hydrologic balance, surface flow disruption, and sediment trapping capacity.

Role in models

Successional stage is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, we expect later successional forests to provide greater mitigation of floodwater than early successional forests.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project (WA/OR).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mean days precipitation per year
page.title: Mean days precipitation per year
page.description:
The number of days of precipitation per year across the landscape.

Role in models

Since the flood models currently run on an annual time scale, assessing overall flood regulation capacity rather than being event-based, the mean number of days of precipitation per year is used as a proxy for how often the soils are saturated. If rainfall is relatively uncommon, the landscape may better be able to absorb floodwater than in wetter regions. Mean days of precipitation per month data are also available. To run flood models on an event-by-event basis, we would need data or proxies for variables like soil saturation, precipitation, and snowmelt which often have limited availability on a landscape scale.

Representation

Data are categorical, and have been pre-discretized based on the number of days of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See http://www.ems-i.com/wmshelp/Hydrologic_Models/Calculators/Composite_Runoff_Coefficients/Selecting_the_Method.htm.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. We use HSG along with slope and impervious surface data to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

SSURGO soils data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope strongly affects runoff by influencing potential infiltration.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, we use slope data along with HSG and impervious surface data to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models. Greater infiltration is expected on level slopes than on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Data are derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent impervious cover
page.title: Percent impervious cover
page.description:
The amount of impervious surface (buildings, roads, parking lots, etc.) on the landscape.

Role in models

We use impervious surface along with slope and hydrologic soils group to estimate the soil infiltration component of flood control in the flood sink models. Zero infiltration is expected on impervious surfaces.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the land surface under impervious cover.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation height
page.title: Vegetation height
page.description:
Height of the tree canopy above the ground surface.

Role in models

Vegetation height is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, we expect taller tree canopies to intercept more precipitation, leading to greater mitigation of floodwater than forests of shorter stature.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters, representing height of the tree canopy above the ground surface.

Source

Puget Sound LIDAR Consortium.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover. Tree canopy cover influences rooting depths, root densities, and transpiration rates, affecting their ability to aid in infiltration of floodwater.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation and soils, or "green infrastructure" in infiltrating floodwater. All else being equal, we expect greater infiltration and evapotranspiration (under longer time scales), leading to greater mitigation of floodwater under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

)2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration of water.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to the probabilistic model of the "green infrastructure" component of flood regulation. Certain land cover types, such as wetlands, forests, and grasslands are likely to have greater capacity for flood regulation than developed or cultivated land cover types.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration of water.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to the probabilistic model of the "green infrastructure" component of flood regulation. Certain land cover types, such as wetlands, forests, and grasslands are likely to have greater capacity for flood regulation than developed or cultivated land cover types.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

U.S. Forest Service.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Green infrastructure storage
page.title: Green infrastructure storage
page.description:
The total floodwater absorption and detention capacity in soils, vegetation, and floodplains.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of soil, vegetation, and their saturation on floodwater absorption and detention capacity. Results are summed with "gray infrastructure" storage to give total flood regulation values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and beneficiaries at risk of flooding.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of floodwater regulated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Dam storage
page.title: Dam storage
page.description:
The storage capacity of floodwater by dams.

Role in models

Where dams are present, we can use data on typical storage capacity to estimate their contribution toward flood regulation. This storage is summed with detention basin storage to give total "gray infrastructure" storage, which is then summed with "green infrastructure" storage to estimate total natural and artificial flood regulation capacity.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater detention capacity by reservoir.

Source

National Atlas of the United States, Major Dams of the United States.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Detention basin storage
page.title: Detention basin storage
page.description:
Storage of flood waters in detention basins.

Role in models

Where detention basins are present, we assume a given level of flood regulation due to storage of floodwater in basins. This storage is summed with storage behind dams to give total "gray infrastructure" storage, which is then summed with "green infrastructure" storage to estimate total natural and artificial flood regulation capacity.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of detention basins.

Source

County stormwater managment data (where available).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Gray infrastructure storage
page.title: Gray infrastructure storage
page.description:
The sum of storage of floodwater by dams, detention basins, or other types of engineered infrastructure.

Role in models

Results are summed with "green infrastructure" storage to give total flood regulation values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual flood mitigation given the location of sources of floodwater and beneficiaries at risk of flooding.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year.

Source

Calculated deterministically as the sum of dam and detention basin storage.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual flood sink
page.title: Annual flood sink
page.description:
The sum of "green" and "gray" infrastructure influences, e.g., all rainwater and floodwater detained and infiltrated by natural features and engineered infrastructure.

Role in models

The annual flood sink is the total potential flood regulation by both natural and artificial flood control features. These data are passed to the flood flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of lives and property at risk from flood flows.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of floodwater absorbed or detained per year.

Source

Calculated as the sum of outputs from a probabilistic model of "green infrastructure" storage plus storage capacity of artificial detention basins and dams.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: 100-year floodplain extent
page.title: 100-year floodplain
page.description:
The extent of the mapped 100-year floodplain.

Role in models

Floodplain extents are used in the use models to identify the presence of lives and property located in the flood zone. These are the beneficiaries of flood regulation, who are at risk of flooding in the absence of natural or engineered flood control measures. Floodplain extents are also used in the flood flow models to distribute floodwater across the floodplain.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing extent of the 100-year floodplain.

Source

FEMA Q3 Flood Data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: 500-year floodplain extent
page.title: 500-year floodplain
page.description:
The extent of the mapped 500-year floodplain.

Role in models

Floodplain extents are used in the use models to identify the presence of lives and property located in the flood zone. These are the beneficiaries of flood regulation, who are at risk of flooding in the absence of natural or engineered flood control measures. Floodplain extents are also used in the flood flow models to distribute floodwater across the floodplain.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing extent of the 500-year floodplain.

Source

FEMA Q3 Flood Data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Presence of housing
page.title: Presence of housing
page.description:
Residences at risk of flood damage or inundation, potentially leading to loss of life or property during flood events.

Role in models

Housing locations are intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of housing.

Source

County assessors' offices (where available) or NLCD developed land (otherwise).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Highways
page.title: Highways
page.description:
Highways at risk of flood damage or inundation, limiting their use for transportation during flood events.

Role in models

Highway locations are summed with railway locations then intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of highways.

Source

TIGER highway line file data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Railways
page.title: Railways
page.description:
Railways at risk of flood damage or inundation, limiting their use for transportation during flood events.

Role in models

Railway locations are summed with highway locations then intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of railways.

Source

TIGER railway line file data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Public assets
page.title: Public assets
page.description:
Public assets at risk of flood damage or inundation, limiting their use during flood events.

Role in models

Public assets are currently estimated by summing highway and railway presence data then intersecting these locations with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values. Other types of public infastructure at risk of flooding could also be added to the public assets layer, assuming data were available to show locations of locally important infrastructure.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of public infrastructure in floodplains.

Source

TIGER highway and railway line file data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland
page.title: Farmland
page.description:
Farmland at risk of flood damage to crops.

Role in models

Farmland locations are intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of flood regulation. The flood flow model is then used to estimate actual flood regulation values.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of farmland.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Residents in 100-year floodplain
page.title: Residents in 100-year floodplain
page.description:
Residents with housing located in the 100-year floodplain are a beneficiary group who may have life and property protected by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of residences at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of residences in the 100-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 100-year floodplain data and housing locations from county assessors' offices (where available) or NLCD developed land (otherwise).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Residents in 500-year floodplain
page.title: Residents in 500-year floodplain
page.description:
Residents with housing located in the 500-year floodplain are a beneficiary group who may have life and property protected by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of residences at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of residences in the 500-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 500-year floodplain data and housing locations from county assessors' offices (where available) or NLCD developed land (otherwise).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Public assets in 100-year floodplain
page.title: Public assets in 100-year floodplain
page.description:
Roads and railways located in the 100-year floodplain are a beneficiary group whose protection by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure helps avoid public replacement and repair costs and maximize access during high precipitation events.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of public assets at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of public infrastructure in the 100-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 100-year floodplain data and TIGER road and rail data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Public assets in 500-year floodplain
page.title: Public assets in 500-year floodplain
page.description:
Roads and railways located in the 500-year floodplain are a beneficiary group whose protection by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure helps avoid public replacement and repair costs and maximize access during high precipitation events.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of public assets at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of public infrastructure in the 500-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 500-year floodplain data and TIGER road and rail data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland in 100-year floodplain
page.title: Farmland in 100-year floodplain
page.description:
Farmland located in the 100-year floodplain is a beneficiary group whose protection by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure helps avoid crop damage and loss during flood events.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of farmland at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of farmland in the 100-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 100-year floodplain data and NLCD farmland cover data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland in 500-year floodplain
page.title: Farmland in 500-year floodplain
page.description:
Farmland located in the 500-year floodplain is a beneficiary group whose protection by ecosystems and engineered flood control infrastructure helps avoid crop damage and loss during flood events.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for flood regulation. The location of farmland at risk of flooding is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual flood risk, given precipitation levels and the location of sinks that reduce flood flows.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of farmland in the 500-year floodplain.

Source

Intersection of FEMA 500-year floodplain data and NLCD farmland cover data.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

River and stream locations, or hydrography data, are used to route floodwater across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which floodwater then follows, spreading across the floodplain as it moves downstream.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of rivers and streams.

Source

CalTrans Teale Data Center; Washington Department of Natural Resources.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route floodwater across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which floodwater then follows, spreading across the floodplain as it moves downstream.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Levees
page.title: Levees
page.description:
Levees restrict floodwater to the river channel, protecting lives and property immediately behind the levee as long as it is not breached, but speeding the flow of floodwater downstream.

Role in models

Levee location data are used in the flow model to limit the spread of floodwater across the floodplain when levees are present.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of levees.

Source

County GIS offices (where available).
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging flood flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow route of floodwater across the landscape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows estimation of the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potentially damaging runoff
page.title: Source of potentially damaging runoff
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows runoff capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential flood damage
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users on the landscape that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks. For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows people and property receiving damage when accounting for sources of floodwater and its flow path but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from floodwater.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual flood
page.title: Actual flood flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows represents floodwater that impacts people or property, after accounting for flood routing due to topography, stream networks, and natural and artificial features that detain, slow, or infiltrate floodwater.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging runoff
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows runoff that actually harms people or damages property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized runoff mitigation
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows sinks that actively reduce floodwater, providing the benefit of reduced flood damage for people.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Flood damage received
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows actual damage received by people and property when accounting for sources of floodwater and their sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Absorbed floodwater
page.title: Absorbed flood flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flood flows that are absorbed by sinks prior to reaching human beneficiaries of flood regulation.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mitigated floodwater
page.title: Mitigated flood source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the portion of the total runoff that is absorbed, detained, or slowed by the action of flood sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Flood mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from flood damage due to the flood regulation activity of sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.
